titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cipe Pineles papers, 1925-2005 and undated RL.11739

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-06-25 16:18:46 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Cipe Pineles was an Austrian-born Jewish artist noted for innovations in magazine design, illustration and typography, based primarily in New York. Collection includes correspondence, photographs, drawings and illustrations and other design work, paintings, advertising and promotional materials, drafts of manuscripts, recipes, financial records and other printed materials that document Pineles's professional and private life, including correspondence and service orders during World War II. Collection also includes materials relating to a number of individuals: Ben Shahn, Carol Burton Fripp, Edward Sorel, Jay Leyda, John Alcorn, Mehemed Fehmy Agha, Sidney Meyers, Will Burtin and William Golden. Institutions represented in the collection include Alliance graphique internationale, American Institute of Graphic Arts, Art Directors Club, Harvard Graduate School of Design, Lincoln Center, Parsons School of Design and the Pratt Institute. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.
did.langmaterial: Materials in English; German; Hebrew; Polish; Yiddish.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: General Files; Activities and Projects; Correspondence; Organizations; People; and Photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Cipe Pineles was an Austrian-born Jewish artist noted for innovations in magazine design, illustration and typography, based primarily in New York.

Born 1910 Austria; emigrate to US 1923. Bay Ridge High School, Brooklyn 1924-1926; Pratt Institute 1927-1930. Work: designer, Contempora 1931-1933; Assistant to Art Director, Conde Nast 1933-1936; Associate Art Director, Vogue 1936-1937; Art Director, Glamour 1938-1944; Art Director, Overseas Woman 1945-1946; Art Director, Seventeen 1947-1950; Art Director, Charm magazine 1950-1959; Art Director, Mademoiselle 1960-1961; Free lance designer, Will Burtin Inc. 1962-1972; Design Consultant, Lincoln Center 1965-1970; Director of Publication Design, Parsons School of Design 1970-1984; Visiting Committee, Harvard Graduate School of Design 1978-1981. First woman member of Art Directors Club 1948; Art Directors Club Hall of Fame 1975. Died 1991 New York.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Cipe Pineles papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Cipe Pineles papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Alyssa Perez and Richard Collier, June 2019;
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0105

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following Hartman Center collections:

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection includes correspondence, photographs, drawings and illustrations and other design work, paintings, advertising and promotional materials, drafts of manuscripts, recipes, financial records and other printed materials that document Pineles's professional and private life, including correspondence and service orders during World War II. Collection also includes materials relating to a number of individuals: Ben Shahn, Carol Burton Fripp, Edward Sorel, Jay Leyda, John Alcorn, Mehemed Fehmy Agha, Sidney Meyers, Will Burtin and William Golden. Institutions represented in the collection include Alliance graphique internationale, American Institute of Graphic Arts, Art Directors Club, Harvard Graduate School of Design, Lincoln Center, Parsons School of Design and the Pratt Institute. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Non-dissenters refers to a term coined by art dealers such as Martin Reymert to denote 19th century European artists who were products of formal training outside the emerging strains of modernist theory in art. Often associated with the collecting habits of Muriel Butkin, who specialized in acquiring drawings from lesser known French artists of the 19th century.
